turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: Now Dyle, you listen to me -- my mama didn't raise no stupid children. I know who's got the money 'n I ain't disappearing till I got my share -- 'n' my share's growin' a whole lot bigger ev'ry day.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Where are you, ol' buddy?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: I'll tell you what, fella -- you want t' find me, you jus' turn 'round -- from now on I'll be right behind you.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: All right -- where's the letter?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: The letter? The letter ain't worth nuthin'.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: You know what I mean -- the envelope with the stamps. I want it.

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: You greenhorn -- you half-witted, thick-skulled, hare-brained, greenhorn! They wuz both too smart for us!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: TEX
turns.text: First her husband, now her -- she hoodwinked you! She batted all them big eyes and you went 'n fell for it - like a egg from a tall chicken! Here!  You want? Here -- it's yours!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Oh, come on!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: -- there has to be a darn good reason for living the way you do. I want to know what it is.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It's simple. I like what I do -- I enjoy doing it. There aren't many men who love their work as much as I do. Look around some time.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Is there a Mrs. Canfield?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Yes, but --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I could eat a horse.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I think that's what you ordered.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Don't you dare to be civil with me! All this time you were leading me on --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: How was I leading you on?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: All that marvelous rejection -- you knew I couldn't resist it. Now it turns out you were only interested in the money.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What would you like me to say -- that a pretty girl with an outrageous manner means more to an old pro like me than a quarter of a million dollars?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No -- I guess not.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It's a toss-up, I can tell you that.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Don't you know I'm having a tough time keeping my eyes off of you?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Oh, you should see your face.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It's lovely.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm not hungry -- isn't it glorious?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Adam!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It's all right -- look.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You don't look so bad in this light.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Why do you think I brought you here?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I thought maybe you wanted me to see the kind of work the competition was turning out.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Pretty good, huh? I taught them everything they do.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh? Did they do that sort of thing way back in your day?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: How do you think I got here?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Aren't you allowed to kiss back?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: No. The doctor said it would be bad for my -- thermostat.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: When you come on, you really come on.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well -- come on.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I know why you're not taken -- no one can catch up with you.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Relax -- you're gaining.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: That wraps it up -- Tex has the money. Go back to bed -- I'll let you know when I've found him.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You're going to look for him -- now?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: If the police find him first they're not very likely to turn over a quarter of a million dollars to us, are they?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Adam --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: There's no time -- I'll call you in the morning.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Open up.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I think we were wrong about Tex having the money.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I just heard from him -- he's still hungry. That means killing Gideon didn't get it for him -- so he's narrowed it down to us. You've got it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I've looked, Adam -- you know I have --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Where's that airlines bag?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Lord, you're stubborn.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I sure am. Get it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But everyone and his Aunt Lilian's been through that bag. Somebody would have seen it.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Let's look anyway.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Lord, you're stubborn.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I mean, it's there, Reggie. If only we could see it. We're looking at it right now.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Electric razor -- comb -- steamship ticket -- fountain pen -- four passports -- toothbrush -- wallet --  key -- what about that?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: To the apartment -- it matches mine perfectly.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: The letter --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It still doesn't make sense, but it isn't worth any quarter of a million either. Have we forgotten anything?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The tooth powder. Wait a minute -- could you recognize heroin just by tasting it?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Heroin -- peppermint-flavored heroin.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, I guess that's it -- dead end.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Go to bed. You've got to be at work in the morning. There's nothing more we can do tonight.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I love you, Adam.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Yes, you told me.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No -- last time I said "I love you, Alex."

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- I think I've found --  are you on?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, it's all right. What's wrong, Adam?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Nothing's wrong. I think I found something. I was snooping around Tex's room and I found this in the waste basket. I've stuck it back together.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You're right. I remember Grandpierre looking through it. But there was nothing in it -- at least, nothing that the police thought was very important.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Can you remember anything at all?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Grandpierre asked me about an appointment Charles had -- on the day he was killed.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: With whom? Where?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I think it only said where -- but I can't --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Think, Reggie, you've got to think -- it may be what we're looking for.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: That money's not ours, Adam -- if we keep it, we'll be breaking the law.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Nonsense. We didn't steal it. There's no law against stealing stolen money.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Of course there is!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: There is? Well, I can't say I think very much of a silly law like that. Think, Reggie -- please think -- what was written in Charles' notebook?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well -- it was a place -- a street corner, I think. But I don't --  Hold it. I'm on.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: as outlined in report number three- nine-stroke-five-two of the Western Hemisphere Conference held on March 22 --  no wait! It was last Thursday, five o'clock at the Jardin des Champs- Élysées! Adam -- that was it! The garden!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It's Thursday today -- and it's almost five -- come on!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Now what?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Five o'clock -- Thursday -- the Garden -- it's got to be something around here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But Charles' appointment was last week, not --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I know, but this is all we've got left.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, you're right there. Ten minutes ago I had a job.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Stop grousing. If we find the money I'll buy you an international conference all your own. Now start looking. You take this side and I'll poke around over there.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It's hopeless -- I don't even know what we're looking for.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: It's all right -- I don't think Tex does, either.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Tex? You mean he's here, too?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Look.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- stop!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why? So you can kill me too? Tex is dead, I've seen him! He said Dyle did it!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I'm not Dyle -- you know that!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But Tex didn't -- he still thought -- !

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Don't be an idiot!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- why won't you listen?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm through listening to you!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: But I didn't kill anybody.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Then who did? You're the only one left.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- please believe me!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He's -- with the C.I.A. -- I've seen him at the Embassy.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Don't be a fool! He's Carson Dyle!

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- listen to me!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You lied to me so many times --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- trust me once more -- please.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Can I really believe you this time, Adam?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: There's not a reason on earth why you should.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You didn't have to chase me so hard --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Here, give it to me.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry I thought you were the murderer, Adam -- how did I know that he was as big a liar as you are?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: And that's all the gratitude I get for saving your hide.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The truth, now -- was it my hide -- or the stamps?

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What a terrible thing to say. How could you even think that?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: All right, prove it to me -- tell me to go to the Embassy first thing in the morning and turn in those stamps.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I said, tell me to go to the --

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: I heard you, I heard you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Then say it.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: Reggie -- listen to me --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Never mind -- I'll go by myself.

turns.speaker: ADAM
turns.text: What makes you think they're even interested? It's only a quarter of a million -- it'll cost more than that to fix up their bookkeeping. As a taxpayer --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I'm sorry -- my secretary must have gone to lunch. You are -- ?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Mrs. Lampert -- Mrs. Charles Lampert.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Come in, Mrs. Lampert. You're quite late.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Dry-cleaningwise, things are all fouled up. I had a good man -- an excellent man on the Rue Ponthieu, but H.Q. asked us to use the plant here in the building -- to ease the gold outflow.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- are you sure you know who I am?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Charles Lampert's widow -- yes?  Last time I sent out a tie only the spot came back.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Have some, please. I've got...  ...liverwurst -- liverwurst -- chicken and -- liverwurst.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Do you know what C.I.A. is, Mrs. Lampert?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't suppose it's an airline, is it?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Central Intelligence Agency -- C.I.A.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You mean spies and things like that?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Only we call them agents.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: We? You mean you're --?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Someone has to do it, Mrs. Lampert --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry, it's just that I didn't think that you people were supposed to admit --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I'm not an agent, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm an administrator -- a desk jockey -- trying to run a bureau of overworked men with under-allocated funds. Congress seems to think that all a spy needs --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Agent.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Yes -- That all he needs is a code book and a cyanide pill and he's in business.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What's all this got to do with me, Mr. Bartholomew?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Your husband was wanted by the U. S. government.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: May I have a sandwich, please?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: To be more specific, he was wanted by this agency.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: So that was it.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Yes. We knew him, of course, by his real name.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: His -- real -- ?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Voss -- Charles Voss. All right, Mrs. Voss --  -- I'd like you to look at this photograph, please -- by the way, you saw this one, didn't you?  Scott, Cathy, and Ham, Jr.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Very sweet.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Aren't they?  Now look at this one, Mrs. Voss, and --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Stop calling me that! Lampert's the name on the marriage license.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Yes -- and tell me if you recognize anyone. Just a moment. Have a good look.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Mrs. Lampert, I'm afraid you're in a great deal of danger.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Danger? Why should I be in any danger?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: You're Charles Voss's wife -- now that he's dead you're their only lead.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- if you're trying to frighten me you're doing a really first-rate job!

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Please, do what we ask, Mrs. Lampert -- it's your only chance.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Gladly, only I don't know what you want! You haven't told me.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Oh, haven't I? The money -- Mrs. Lampert -- the money. The $250,000 Charles Voss received from the auction. Those three men want it, too -- they want it very badly.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But it's Charles's money, not theirs.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Oh, Mrs. Lampert! I'd love to see you try and convince them of that!  Oh, dear.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Then whose is it? His or theirs?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Ours.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh, I see.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: And I'm afraid we want it back.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But I don't have it.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: That's impossible. You're the only one who could have it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry it's impossible. It's the truth.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I believe you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Thanks very much.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Oh, you've got the money all right -- you just don't know you've got it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- if I had a quarter of a million dollars, believe me, I'd know it.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Nevertheless, Mrs Lampert -- you've got it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You mean it's just lying around someplace -- all that cash?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Or a safe deposit key, a certified check, a baggage claim -- you look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm quite sure you'll find it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- look just as hard and as fast as you can. You may not have a great deal of time. Those men know you have it just as surely as we do. You won't be safe until the money's in our hands. Is that clear?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Here's where you're to call me -- day or night. It's a direct line to both my office and my apartment. Don't lose it, Mrs. Lampert -- and please don't tell anyone about coming to see me. It could prove fatal for them as well as yourself.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Wait a minute -- you think those three men killed Charles, don't you?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: We've no proof, of course, but we rather think so, yes.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, there you are! Charles had the money with him -- so whoever killed him has it -- they have it!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Because they're still here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Like I said, Mrs Lampert -- I'm afraid you're in a great deal of danger. Remember what happened to Charles.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I don't know who this Mr. Dyle is, but it's just possible we were wrong about who killed your husband.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You mean he might have -- Mr. Bartholomew, I'm catching the next plane out of here -- I'm not going to sit here and wait for someone to make chopped liver out of me!

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Where are you now -- can you meet me? Do you know Les Halles?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, where?  -- in fifteen minutes. I'll be there.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What did you want to see me about, Mr. Bartholomew?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Were you followed?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, but I lost him. I really did it quite brilliantly. I'm beginning to think women make the best spies.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Agents.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He has a gun, Mr. Bartholomew -- I saw it.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Dyle, or whatever his name is.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: What does your Mr. Dyle look like, Mrs. Lampert?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He's hardly my Mr. Dyle.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Describe him.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well -- he's tall -- over six feet -- rather thin -- in good physical shape, I'd say -- dark eyes -- quite handsome, really.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, what?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: That's not Carson Dyle.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Carson?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: There's only one Dyle connected with this affair, Mrs. Lampert -- that's Carson.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You mean you've known about him all along? Why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Mr. Bartholomew -- why didn't you tell me you knew about Dyle?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I didn't see any point. Dyle's dead.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Dead? Mr. Bartholomew -- maybe you'd better tell me what this thing's all about.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I suppose you're old enough to have heard of World War Two?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Barely, yes.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: In 1944, five members of the O.S.S. -- the military espionage unit -- were ordered behind the German lines for the purpose of delivering $250,000 in gold to the French Underground. The five men --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Café.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Gratinée, choucroute garnie, salade de pommes -- et un ballon de rouge.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Mrs. Lampert, I really hadn't planned on spending the entire night here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Can I at least keep the onion soup?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Go on, please -- five men -- $250,000 -- the French Underground --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Yes. The five men. They were, of course, your husband, Charles, the three men who showed up at his funeral yesterday, and Carson Dyle. But something went wrong and they were unable to locate their contact. It must have been at that point that they decided to steal the money.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Steal it how?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: By burying it, and then reporting that the Germans had captured it. All they had to do was come back after the war, dig it up and split it five ways -- a quarter of a million dollars with no questions asked.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: May I have a cigarette, please?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Have you any idea what these things cost over here?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Please go on, Mr. Bartholomew -- what happened then?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Scobie was able to travel, but Carson Dyle was clearly dying, so they --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Carson was dying so they were forced to leave him. They finally got back to the base, made their report, and waited for the war to end. Only Charles couldn't wait quite as long as the others. He beat them back to the gold, took everything for himself and disappeared. It's taken Gideon, Tex and Scobie all this time to catch up with him again.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But if they stole all that money -- why can't you arrest them?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: We know what happened from the bits and pieces we were able to paste together -- but we still have no proof.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But what has all this got to do with the C.I.O.?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: C.I.A., Mrs. Lampert. We're an extension of the wartime O.S.S. It was our money and we want it back.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Bartholomew, but nothing you've told me has changed my mind. I still intend leaving Paris -- tonight.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I wouldn't advise that, Mrs. Lampert. You'd better consider what happened to your husband when he tried to leave. Those men won't be very far away -- no matter where you go. In fact, I don't even see any point in your changing hotels. Please help us, Mrs. Lampert. Your government is counting on you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, if I'm going to die, I might as well do it for my country.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: That's the spirit.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh, stop it. What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: We're anxious to know who this man is -- the one calling himself Dyle.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Maybe he really is Dyle. He could still be alive.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: No, Mrs. Lampert.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But no one actually saw him die.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: No, Mrs. Lampert. His death is registered with the War Department in Washington.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh. Then who's this one?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I don't know -- but I think you'd better find out, don't you?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Me? Why me?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: You're in an ideal position -- he trusts you.  Besides, you said yourself, women make the best spies.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Agents.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes -- ?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Mrs. Lampert? -- Bartholomew. I've spoken to Washington, Mrs. Lampert --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Go ahead, Mr. Bartholomew -- I'm listening.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: I told them what you said -- about this man being Carson Dyle's brother. I asked them what they knew about it and they told me -- you're not gonna like this, Mrs. Lampert -- they told me Carson Dyle has no brother.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Are you sure there's no mistake?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: None whatsoever. Please, Mrs. Lampert -- be careful.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Just a minute, Mrs. Lampert -- you'd better give that to me slowly. Who's Adam?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The one who said he was Dyle's brother -- of course I'm sure -- Tex wrote the word 'Dyle' before he died. He's the murderer I tell you -- he's the only one left! You've got to do something!

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: Calm down, Mrs. Lampert -- please. Does he have the money?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, I do -- it was the stamps on that letter Charles had with him on the train. They were in plain sight all the time, but no one ever bothered looking at the envelope.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW
turns.text: The envelope -- imagine that.  Mrs. Lampert, listen to me -- you're not safe as long as you've got these stamps. Go to the Embassy right away -- wait, I'd better meet you halfway -- it's quicker. Now, let's see -- do you know the center garden at the Palais Royal? -- yes, by the colonnade -- as soon as you can get there. Hurry, Mrs. Lampert.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, I'm leaving now -- goodbye.

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: It's Charles!

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: Very good.

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: He looks so young -- when was this taken?

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: 1944. The next face, please.

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: It's the man who came to the funeral yesterday -- I'm sure of it -- a tall man in a corduroy suit and string tie.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: Does the name Tex Penthollow mean anything to you?

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: Next, please.

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes -- and he was there, too -- a little fatter now -- and less hair -- but it's the same one.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: Do you know him, Mrs. Vo -- Mrs. Lampert? Leopold W. Gideon?

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: The last one, please.

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: That's a face you don't forget -- he was there too --

turns.speaker: BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE
turns.text: Herman Scobie. And you've never seen him before, either?

turns.speaker: REGGIE'S VOICE
turns.text: No, thank heaven.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, of all the mean, rotten, contemptible, crooked --

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Crooked? I should think you'd be glad to find out I wasn't crooked.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You couldn't even be honest about being dishonest. Why didn't you say something?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: We're not allowed to tell. May I have the stamps, please?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Here --  Wait a minute -- how did Carson Dyle get an office in here, anyway?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: When did you see him -- what time, I mean?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Around one.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: The lunch hour. He probably worked it out in advance. He found an office that was usually left open and just moved in for the time you were here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Then how do I know this is your office?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Mrs. Foster -- send a memo to Bartholomew at Security recommending that --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Bartholomew?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: -- recommending that all Embassy offices be locked during the lunch hour.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Starting with his own.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Okay, now -- hand over those stamps.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What's your first name today?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Brian.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Brian Cruikshank -- it would serve me right if I got stuck with that one.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Who asked you to get stuck with any of them?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Is there a Mrs. Cruikshank?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But you're -- divorced?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: My mother -- she lives in Detroit. Come on now -- give me those stamps.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Only if you can prove to me that you're really Brian Cruikshank.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: How about if next week some time I put it on a marriage license -- that ought to --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Quit stalling -- I want to see some identification -- now!

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: I wouldn't lie on a thing like that -- I could go to jail.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You'd lie about anything.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Well, maybe we'd better forget about it, then.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You can't prove it, can you? You're still trying to --  marriage license! Did you say -- ?

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: I didn't say anything. Will you give me those stamps?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You did too say it -- I heard you. Oh, I love you Adam -- I mean Alex -- er, Peter -- Brian. I hope we have lots of boys -- we can name them all after you.

turns.speaker: CRUIKSHANK
turns.text: Before we start on that, do you mind handing over the stamps?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: If you do anything funny, or try to talk to anyone, I'll kill you, Dyle -- here and now. Okay?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: You'll wreck your raincoat.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: We wait -- with our mouths shut.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: How long do you intend -- ?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: I said with the mouth shut.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Sorry about that.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Okay -- up there.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Do I knock or something?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Open it.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Keep going.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: The view had better be worth it.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Very pretty. Now what?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: I'll give you a chance, Dyle -- which is more than you'd give me. Where's the money?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Is that why you dragged me all the way up here -- to ask me that? She has it -- you know that.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: And I say maybe you both have it! One more time, Dyle -- where is it?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Supposing I did have it -- which I don't -- do you really think I'd hand it over?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: You're out, Dyle -- right now!

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Back where?

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: That's the idea.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: And stop threatening that boy. He doesn't have the money. Mrs. Lampert doesn't either.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Then who does?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I don't know, Herman -- maybe you do.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Or you --  Or you --

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: That's a crock! If one of us did that he wouldn't hang around here waiting for the other two to wise up.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: But he'd have to. If he left he'd be admitting his guilt -- and the others would know what happened. Whoever it is has to wait here, pretending to look for the money, waiting for the rest of us to give up and go home. That's when he'll be safe and not a minute before.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: He's just tryin' to throw us off! They've got it, I tell you! Why don't we search their rooms?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: It's all right with us --

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: Not my room!

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: What's wrong, Herman -- have you got something to hide?  Then I take it there are no objections.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: We'd better exchange keys. Here's mine.

turns.speaker: SCOBIE
turns.text: I'll take that.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Dyle.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Reggie?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It's the only name I've got. How about you?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: No cat and mouse -- you've got me. What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why you lied to me.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I had to -- for all I knew you could have been in on the whole thing.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well, you know now, so please tell me who you are.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: But you know my name -- it's Dyle.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Carson Dyle is dead.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Yes, he is. He was my brother.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Your --

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: The army thinks he was killed in action by the Germans, but I think they did it -- Tex, Gideon and Scobie -- and your husband -- because he wouldn't go along with their scheme to steal the gold. I think he threatened to turn them in and they killed him. I'm trying to prove it. They think I'm working with them. But I'm not, and that's the truth. I'm on your side, Reggie -- please believe that.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How can I? You lied to me -- the way Charles did -- and after promising you wouldn't. Oh, I want to believe you, Peter... oh, but I can't call you that anymore, can I? It will take me a while to get used to your new name -- which I don't even know yet. What is it?  Aren't you going to tell me?  Hello -- ?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Didn't anyone ever tell you it's impolite to --  What happened?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I met a man with sharp nails.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Scobie?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I left him hanging around the American Express.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Come on -- I've got something that stings like crazy.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Listen -- all I really want is an estimate.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It's not so bad. You may not be able to lie on your back for a few days -- but, then, you can lie from any position, can't you?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Does it hurt?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Haven't you got a bullet I can bite?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Are you really Carson Dyle's brother?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Would you like to see my passport?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Your passport! What kind of a proof is that?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Would you like to see where I was tattooed?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Okay, I'll drive you around there some day.  Ouch!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Ha ha. You could at least tell me what your first name is these days.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Alexander.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Is there a Mrs. Dyle?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Yes, but we're divorced.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I thought that was Peter Joshua.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I'm no easier to live with than he was.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: There -- you're a new man.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I'm sorry I couldn't tell you the truth, but I had to find out your part in all this.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Alex -- how can you tell if someone is lying or not?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: You can't.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: There must be some way.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: There's an old riddle about two tribes of Indians -- the Whitefeet always tell the truth and the Blackfeet always lie. So one day you meet an Indian, you ask him if he's a truthful Whitefoot or a lying Blackfoot? He tells you he's a truthful Whitefoot, but which one is he?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why couldn't you just look at his feet?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Because he's wearing moccasins.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh. Well, then he's a truthful Whitefoot, of course.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Why not a lying Blackfoot?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Which one are you?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Whitefoot, of course.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I hope it turns out you're a Whitefoot, Alex -- I could be very happy hanging around the tepee.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Reggie -- listen to me --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh-oh -- here it comes. The fatherly talk. You forget I'm already a widow.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: So was Juliet -- at fifteen.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm not fifteen.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Well, there's your trouble right there -- you're too old for me.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Why can't you be serious?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: There, you said it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Said what?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Serious. When a man gets to be my age that's the last word he ever wants to hear. I don't want to be serious -- and I especially don't want you to be.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Okay -- I'll tell you what -- we'll just sit around all day long being frivolous -- how about that?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Now please, Reggie -- cut it out.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Cutting it out.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Who told you to do that?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: But I'm not through complaining yet.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Now please, Reggie -- cut it out.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I think I love you, Alex --

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: The phone's ringing --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Whoever it is won't give up -- and neither will I.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: They've got Jean-Louis!

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: That sounds like their problem.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'll be right there.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What day is it?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Tuesday.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Lord, I forgot all about it -- Sylvie works late Tuesday nights -- she always leaves him with me. They wouldn't do anything to a little boy, would they?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I don't know -- it depends on whether or not they've already eaten.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Hello, Herman, it was a happy landing, I see.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'd better call Sylvie -- she must be frantic.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Come on -- let's get busy. Who gets your vote?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Scobie -- he's the one that objected.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: He's all yours. I'll do Tex and Gideon. Take Jean-Louis with you -- and make sure you bolt the door from inside.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Viens, Jean-Louis -- we're going to have a treasure hunt.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Reggie -- ? Did you find it?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Who do you think did it -- Gideon?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Or Tex?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You're a big help. Can I have one of those?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I think Tex did it.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Because I really suspect Gideon -- and it is always the person you don't suspect.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Do women think it's feminine to be so illogical -- or can't they help it?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What's so illogical about that?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: A) It's always the person you don't suspect; B) that means you think it's Tex because you really suspect Gideon; therefore C) if you think it's Tex, it has to be someone else -- Gideon.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh. I guess they just can't help it.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Women. You know, I can't help feeling rather sorry for Scobie.  Wouldn't it be nice if we were like that?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: What -- like Scobie?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No -- Gene Kelly. Remember the way he danced down there next to the river in 'American in Paris' -- without a care in the world? This is good, want some?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I'd love some, thanks.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: No sense messing up the streets.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Alex --

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I'm scared.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Don't worry, I'm not going to hit you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No, about Scobie, I mean. I can't think of any reason why he was killed.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Maybe somebody felt that four shares were too many --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What makes you think that this somebody will be satisfied with three? He wants it all, Alex -- that means we're in his way, too.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Yes, I know.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: First your brother, then Charles, now Scobie -- we've got to do something! Any minute now we could be assassinated! Would you do anything like that?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: What? Assassinate somebody?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No --

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Hurry up and change -- I'm starved.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Let me know what you want -- I'll pick a suit that matches.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Got you.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Did you ever hear the story of the boy who cried wolf?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The shower's in there.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Reggie -- open the door.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: This is a ludicrous situation. There must be dozens of men dying to use my shower.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Then I suggest you call one of them.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I dare you.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Have you ever heard of anyone taking a shower with his shoes on?  What a nut.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I usually sing a medley of old favorites when I bathe -- any requests?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Shut the door!

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I don't think I know that one.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: The suit needs it more than I do, anyway.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How often do you go through this little ritual?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Every day. The manufacturer recommends it.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Reggie -- you haven't spoken a word in twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I keep thinking about Charles and Scobie -- and the one who's going to be next -- me?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Nothing's going to happen to you while I'm around -- I want you to believe that.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: How can I believe it when you don't even know who the killer is? I've got that right, haven't I? You don't know who did it.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: No -- not yet.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But then if we sit back and wait, the field should start narrowing down, shouldn't it? Whoever's left alive at the end will pretty well have sewn up the nomination, wouldn't you say so?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Are you trying to say that I might have killed Charles and Scobie?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: What do I have to do to satisfy you -- become the next victim?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It's a start, anyway.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I don't understand you at all -- one minute you're chasing me around the shower room and the next you're accusing me of murder.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Carson Dyle didn't have a brother.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: I can explain if you'll just listen. Will you listen?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I can't very well leave without a pair of water wings.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Okay. Then get set for the story of my life -- not that it would ever make the best-seller list.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Fiction or non-fiction?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Why don't you shut up!

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Well!

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Are you going to listen?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: After I graduated college I was all set to go into my father business. Umbrella frames -- that's what he made. It was a sensible business, I suppose, but I didn't have the sense to be interested in anything sensible.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I suppose all this is leading somewhere?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: It led me away from umbrella frames, for one thing. But that left me without any honest means of support.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: When a man has no profession except the one he loathes, what's left? I began looking for people with more money than they'd ever need -- including some they'd barely miss.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You mean, you're a thief?

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Well, it isn't exactly the term I'd have chosen, but I suppose it captures the spirit of the thing.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Well, I can't really blame you -- not now.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But I do believe it -- that's what I don't believe. So it's goodbye Alexander Dyle -- Welcome home Peter Joshua.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: Sorry, the name's Adam Canfield.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Adam Canfield. Wonderful. Do you realize you've had three names in the past two days? I don't even know who I'm talking to any more.

turns.speaker: DYLE
turns.text: The man's the same, even if the name isn't.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: No -- he's not the same. Alexander Dyle was interested in clearing up his brother's death. Adam Canfield is a crook. And with all the advantages you've got -- brains, charm, education, a handsome face --
